questions.text: A 35 y/o woman presents with an incidental liver mass found on ultrasound. Further imaging with CT and MRI is performed, revealing a well-defined mass with a central scar which is hyperintense on T2w MRI. The lesion shows hot spot on sulphur colloid scan. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Feature

FNH

FLC

Ultrasound

It is difficult to detect as it has similar reflectivity to the liver.

Solid, hyperechoic lesions, central scar and calcification may be seen

CT

Well-defined lobulated mass, isoattenuating to liver parenchyma; marked homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase with a central low-attenuation scar, mass effect visible. (Option C)

Well-defined mass, often hyperattenuating; may enhance the arterial phase  (Option D ruled out)

MRI

Isointense on T1, hyperintense on T2; central scar hypointense on T1

Hyperintense on T1 if fat-containing, significant enhancement on arterial phase.

Key Differentiator

Central stellate scar: Enhances on CT/MRI; no calcification

Scar+ , calcification  more common

CT reveals a hypervascular lesion with mosaic enhancement and washout on delayed phases. MRI demonstrates decreased T1 and increased T2 signal intensities with late arterial enhancement. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound (USG)

CT

MRI

• Heterogeneous mass appearance.

• May display a "nodule-in-nodule" pattern.

 

• Hypervascular with mosaic enhancement.

• Washout of contrast observed in the portal venous or delayed phases.

 

• T1: Decreased signal intensity.

• T2: Increased signal intensity.

• Contrast Phases:

◦ Late arterial phase: Hyperenhancement.

◦ Portal venous/delayed phase: Washout, indicating malignancy.

questions.text: A 65 y/o diabetic male presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and signs of sepsis. A USG reveals highly echogenic reflectors with dirty shadowing and ring-down artefacts in the gallbladder. Subsequent CT imaging demonstrates gas within the gallbladder wall and pneumoperitoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55 y/o perimenopausal woman presents with vague abdominal pain. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a large, multilocular cystic lesion in the tail of the pancreas with thick septations and peripheral calcifications. Lab results show elevated CEA levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pseudocysts

• Fluid contains high amylase

• Post-inflammatory, non-neoplastic.

Serous Cystic Neoplasm (SCN)

 

• Common Site: Head of the pancreas.

• Imaging Features: Multiple small cysts, sometimes with central scar calcification.Honeycomb pattern, possible stellate scar.

• Benign: Rarely malignant.

• Common in: Older women in their 6-s-70s - hence called grandmother tumour.

Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm (MCN)

 

• Common Site: Tail of the pancreas.

• Imaging Features: Large, multilocular, thick septations, peripheral calcifications, and sometimes solid components.

• Risk: Malignant transformation

• Common in: Perimenopausal women (40-60 years-Mother tumour.)

Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN)

 

• Types: Main duct, branch duct, mixed.

• Common Site: Ductal origin—main duct or branch duct.

• Risk: Higher malignancy risk in main duct type.

• Main duct IPMNs: Show cystic dilatation of the main duct, enhancing mural nodules, and viscid mucus causing obstruction.

• Protruding ampulla of Vater-Fish mouth appearance

Solid Pseudopapillary Tumor (SPT):

• Imaging Features: Large, encapsulated, solid and cystic mass, often with haemorrhage &necrosis.

• Demographics: Young women (Daughter tumour), particularly in Asian and African-American populations.

questions.text: A 60 y/o man presents with recurrent abdominal pain and jaundice. A CT abdomen reveals a "sausage-shaped" pancreas and long segmental pancreatic duct strictures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Chronic pancreatitis

Autoimmune Pancreatitis

CT scan

• Calcifications within the pancreas.

• Pancreatic atrophy with dilated ductal system.

• Irregularities or strictures of the pancreatic duct.

 

• Diffuse pancreatic enlargement ("sausage-shaped" appearance).

• Homogeneous delayed enhancement of the pancreas.

• Capsule-like rim of low density, suggesting peripancreatic inflammation or fibrosis.

• Ductal narrowing or strictures 

 

MRCP

• Characteristic "chain of lakes" appearance due to alternating strictures and dilatation of the pancreatic duct.

questions.text: A 45 y/o woman with a history of acute pancreatitis presents with persistent abdominal pain and weight loss. A CT scan performed 5 weeks after her initial episode shows a thick-walled fluid collection containing gas bubbles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Pseudocyst (Option A)

Walled-off Necrosis (Option B)

Definition

Encapsulated fluid collection that develops more than 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis.

Encapsulated collection of necrotic material, which develops after 4 weeks in necrotising pancreatitis

Gas Presence

No gas (Option A ruled out)

Gas bubbles may indicate infection

Location

Peripancreatic space (may extend to mediastinum)

Pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues

Imaging findings

Homogeneous low-attenuation fluid with capsule

CT showing pseudocyst

Thick-walled collection may show gas on CT

 

CT Showing “walled off necrosis”

Resolution

Most resolve spontaneously.

If more than 5 cm or recurrent, cystogastrostomy is done

Often requires drainage or necrosectomy if infected

questions.text: A 52 y/o man diagnosed with necrotizing pancreatitis presents with worsening abdominal pain. A CT scan on day 3 of his illness is performed. What is the most likely imaging finding seen on day 3 in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Non-enhancing areas in the pancreatic body and tail

questions.correct_answer: C. Non-enhancing areas in the pancreatic body and tail
questions.explanation:
Bulky Pancreas

• Enlarged pancreas with heterogeneous enhancement.

• Mild thickening of pancreatic tissue.

• Indicative of oedema in acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis.

CECT revealing bulky pancreas

Renal halo sign:

• The "renal halo" sign presents as a high-density outline around the kidney indicating the inflammatory process in acute pancreatitis extending toward the left pancreatic tail and left pararenal space

CECT revealing Renal halo sign

CT Findings

 

Day 1:

• Normally enhancing pancreas

Day 3:

• Significant necrosis observed.

• The greater part of the pancreatic body and tail shows no enhancement.

Post 2 weeks:

• Gas bubbles in the peripancreatic collection are consistent with an infected acute necrotic collection.

questions.text: A 50 y/o man presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past two days. His serum lipase is elevated to five times the normal limit. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated loop of small intestine near the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely imaging sign observed on the X-ray in this patient?
questions.explanation:
X-ray Features

 

• Sentinel loop sign (Option C): 

◦ Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.

◦ Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign

• Colon cut-off sign: 

◦ Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.

◦ Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

Which of the following statements about imaging modalities used in the liver is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: USG is the first-line investigation for hepatic disorders.

options.label: B
options.text: T1-weighted images show a normal liver as hypointense compared to the spleen and kidney.

options.label: C
options.text: CT allows multiphasic examinations, including arterial, portal, and delayed phases.

options.label: D
options.text: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is primarily reserved for therapeutic purposes.

questions.correct_answer: B. T1-weighted images show a normal liver as hypointense compared to the spleen and kidney.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ David Sutton Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume 1, 8th edition, Page 2355- 2357
  • ↳ Grainger and Allison’s Textbook of Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page 599-606
  • ↳ CT triple-phase liver (protocol) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

Imaging Techniques of Liver

 

Ultrasonography

 

• First-line investigation for hepatic disorders. (Option A ruled out)

• Cost-effective and useful for repeated follow-up.

• Elastography quantifies liver stiffness.

• Contrast-enhanced USG evaluates vascularity without radiation exposure.

• Colour Doppler assesses hepatic vessel flow and patency.

Computed Tomography

 

• Investigation of choice for vascular anatomical assessment.

• It is less expensive and more accessible than MRI.

• Excellent for volumetry and surgical feasibility evaluation.

• Allows Triple-phase examinations, including:

◦ Arterial Phase

◦ Portal Phase

◦ Delayed Phase (Option C ruled out)

• If the lesion is enhanced in the arterial phase, it is hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Magnetic Resonance Imaging

 

• Best for assessing liver parenchyma and biliary system.

• Excellent soft tissue resolution.

• Effective in evaluating diffuse liver conditions like steatosis and fibrosis.

• Uses gadolinium-based contrast agents (e.g., Gd-DTPA, Gd-DOTA) for T1 enhancement.

• Breath-hold 3D T1 weighted sequences allow multiphasic examinations similar to CT.

• Hepatobiliary-specific agents target the reticulo-endothelial system (RES) or hepatocytes.

• T1-Weighted Images

◦ Normal Liver Parenchyma: Hyperintense compared to muscle, spleen, and kidney.

◦ Pathological Lesions: Typically T1 hypointense due to higher water or cellular density.

• T2-Weighted Images

◦ Normal Liver Signal: Hypointense compared to spleen, kidney, and pancreas.

◦ Lesions: Usually hyperintense, aiding in detection.

MRI revealed multiple metastatic liver tumours

A- T1 MRI, B- T2 MRI

Digital Subtraction Angiography

 

• Largely reserved for therapeutic purposes. (Option D ruled out)

• Has been superseded by CT and MR angiographies for diagnostics.

questions.text: A 60 y/o jaundiced patient presents with upper abdominal pain. Ultrasound reveals a dilated bile duct, but the cause of obstruction is unclear. What would be the next best non-invasive imaging technique to evaluate this condition?
A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain. An ultrasound shows echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gallbladder

 

Condition

Radiology

Gallbladder calculus

(Option B)

 

• Gallstones, or GB calculi, are the most likely diagnosis in this case, as they typically appear as echogenic foci on ultrasound and produce posterior acoustic shadowing. 

• This shadowing is caused by the solid nature of the stones, which block the transmission of sound waves.

USG

Gallbladder polyp

(Option A ruled out)

 

• They are typically small masses that protrude into the lumen of the gallbladder. 

• On ultrasound, they generally appear as smooth, hyperechoic intraluminal lesions without posterior acoustic shadowing, unlike gallstones.

USG

Gallbladder adenomyomatosis

(Option C ruled out)

 

• This is characterised by thickening of the gallbladder wall, often due to cholesterol crystals or small stones in the Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. 

• On ultrasound, adenomyomatosis presents with a distinctive comet-tail ring-down artefact (due to reverberation from the cystic spaces), which differentiates it from simple shadowing seen with gallstones.

USG

Porcelain gallbladder

(Option D ruled out)

 

• Porcelain gallbladder refers to a calcified gallbladder wall, which appears as a dense shadowing structure on imaging, typically seen on plain radiographs or CT scans.

• It is associated with gallbladder carcinoma.

•  Ultrasound findings of porcelain GB can resemble emphysematous cholecystitis or large stones, but the condition is characterised by the absence of the double-arc shadow sign seen with gallstones.

CT

questions.correct_answer: B. The Mercedes-Benz sign refers to a star-shaped pattern of gas fissuring in gallstones seen on imaging.
questions.explanation:
Gallstones

Renal Stones

Composed of cholesterol, bilirubin, and calcium salts.

Comprises various minerals: calcium oxalate, uric acid, struvite, and cystine.

Gallstones are better visualised on USG.

Renal stones are better seen on CT

Cholesterol stones may be hard to see on X-rays but are identifiable via ultrasound due to acoustic shadows. (Option A ruled out)

Uric acid stones require non-contrast CT for detection, as they may not show on X-rays.

Diagnostic Imaging Techniques

Gallstones

Renal Stones

USG: Commonly used; no ionising radiation.

USG: Limited use.

CT Scans: Highly sensitive for both stones.

CT Scans: Highly sensitive, detects small/radiolucent stones.

X-rays: Limited effectiveness.

X-rays: Effective for calcium oxalate stones.

Condition

Spherical, homogenous, no echoes or Doppler

questions.text: A 65 y/o male presents with severe abdominal pain and elevated liver enzymes. After imaging, he is found to have a suspected bile duct obstruction due to a stone. The physician plans to both visualize and potentially treat the obstruction. Which imaging modality should be chosen?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

Endoscopic Retrograde 

Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Indications

• Indications include suspected bile duct calculus, cholestasis, pre-surgical biliary evaluation, biliary leak, unknown aetiology sclerosing cholangitis, and unsuccessful or contraindicated ERCP.

• Not typically used for interventions. (Option A ruled out)

• It allows for visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater.

• Allows biopsies, stone extraction, and other Interventional procedures like sphincterotomy, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilation.

Suitability for Jaundice

More Suitable for jaundiced patients

Less suitable for jaundiced patients as it is invasive

Imaging Type

Provides anatomical and functional information

Provides dynamic information during contrast introduction

Success Rate

Substantially replaces PTC and ERCP

Success rates of 92%–97%

Complication Rates

Lower complications; no specified rates

Complication rates of 0.9% to 2.3% (severe)

Resolution

Lower spatial and contrast resolution compared to CT-IVC

High spatial resolution for detailed imaging
